docs.lead_paragraph: With just two days left before the end of session, Albany's power triumvirate emerged from behind closed doors today to announce that a consensus had been reached on being patriotic and on saving trees. Meanwhile, tenants in more than one million New York City apartments had to wait at least one more day for the state's expiring rent laws to be renewed by Gov. George E. Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. The rent laws, which were originally set to expire last Sunday, were extended by special legislation today for the third time in a week, with the deadline now being Wednesday.

headline.main: Legislative Time Ticks Away, But To-Do List Seems to Grow

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature slowly whittles away at pending legislation with only two days left before end of session; extends expiring rent laws for third time in a week; passes bills that raise fines on tree thieves and provides benefits package for those serving in armed forces and their families (M)
docs.snippet: With just two days left before the end of session, Albany's power triumvirate emerged from behind closed doors today to announce that a consensus had been reached on being patriotic and on saving trees.    Meanwhile, tenants in more than one million...

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey physicians are planning a 13-day ''rolling'' strike, a one-day shutdown at their offices, starting today, John Shaffer, a spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey, said yesterday. The strikes are to begin in Bergen County and continue in other counties until June 30. They are smaller versions of the doctors' earlier statewide walkout. About 10,000 New Jersey physicians canceled routine checkups and rescheduled elective surgery during the week of Feb. 4 in one of the nation's largest walkouts ever by doctors. The doctors want to draw attention to what they regard as ruinously high premiums for needed malpractice insurance. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Doctors Plan Protest

docs.abstract: New Jersey physicians plan 13 day 'rolling' strike to protest high malpractice insurance premiums; they intend to close their offices for one day each starting with those in Bergen County (S)
docs.snippet: New Jersey physicians are planning a 13-day ''rolling'' strike, a one-day shutdown at their offices, starting today, John Shaffer, a spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey, said yesterday. The strikes are to begin in Bergen County and...

byline.original: By Stacy Albin (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: The state House has approved a bill intended to offset the costs of malpractice insurance for rural doctors. The measure would set up a $10 million fund to subsidize insurance premiums for doctors, particularly those offering obstetrics. The bill's sponsors contend that large payouts in medical malpractice suits are causing doctors' insurance rates to rise, making it difficult for small rural practices to survive. The bill now goes to the Senate. Dave Miller, a spokesman for Senate Democrats, said it had a good chance of passing. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Insurance Aid For Rural Doctors

docs.abstract: Oregon State House approves bill to offset cost of malpractice insurance for rural doctors by setting up $10 million fund to subsidize premiums, particularly for doctors offering obstetrics (S)
docs.snippet: The state House has approved a bill intended to offset the costs of malpractice insurance for rural doctors. The measure would set up a $10 million fund to subsidize insurance premiums for doctors, particularly those offering obstetrics. The bill's...

docs.lead_paragraph: Top officials from mainland China and Hong Kong will sign a free trade agreement on June 30 that will eliminate all tariffs on many goods and remove restrictions on trade in many services, Hong Kong's leader announced this evening. Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, said that in addition to wiping out many tariffs, Beijing would give Hong Kong companies greater access to mainland China's markets for management consulting, legal and accounting services, real estate services, wholesale distribution, construction engineering, medical services, transportation, logistics, tourism, banking, insurance and securities.

headline.main: Hong Kong And China To Sign Pact Easing Trade

docs.abstract: Hong Kong chief executive Tung Chee-hwa say mainland China and Hong Kong are set to sign free trade accord that will end tariffs on many goods and give Hong Kong companies greater access to mainland markets for many services, news conference; foreign business executives note that unless pact excludes Hong Kong subsidiaries of multinational corporations, China would effectively be opening huge back door to its markets (M)
docs.snippet: Top officials from mainland China and Hong Kong will sign a free trade agreement on June 30 that will eliminate all tariffs on many goods and remove restrictions on trade in many services, Hong Kong's leader announced this evening.     Tung Chee-hwa,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate today began what all sides hailed as a historic debate on legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare. Liberals and conservatives immediately signaled that they would seek changes in the bill and file more than 100 amendments. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican whip, voiced the new reality that, for the first time in years, lawmakers were debating a Medicare drug bill considered to have a good chance of passage.

headline.main: Debate Starts on Medicare And Coverage for Drugs

docs.abstract: Senate begins what all sides are hailing as historic debate on legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare; liberals and conservatives file more than 100 amendments to complicated compromise that would create long-promised benefit for 40 million elderly and disabled Medicare beneficiares beginning in 2006; bill would also allow more private insurers to compete for business (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

byline.original: By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court placed strict limits today on the government's ability to medicate mentally ill defendants forcibly to make them competent to stand trial. The use of antipsychotic drugs must be in the defendant's best medical interest and ''substantially unlikely'' to cause side effects that would compromise the fairness of the trial, the court said in a 6-to-3 decision by Justice Stephen G. Breyer. Additionally, the court held, the government's ''important'' interest in bringing the defendant to trial must be unattainable by alternative, less intrusive means.

headline.main: JUSTICES RESTRICT FORCED MEDICATION PRECEDING A TRIAL

docs.abstract: Supreme Court votes, 6-to-3, to place strict limits on government's ability to medicate mentally ill defendants forcibly to make them competent to stand trial; finds use of antipsychotic drugs must be in defendant's best medical interest and 'substantially unlikely' to cause side effects that would compromise fairness of trial; court holds government's 'important' interest in bringing defendant to trial must be unattainable by alternative, less intrusive means; Justice Stephen G Breyer, writing for majority, says circumstances permitting involuntary administration of antipsychotic drugs 'may be rare' whether defendant has been accused of violent or, as in this case, nonviolent crime; decision overturns ruling by federal appeals court in St Louis authorizing forced medication of Dr Charles T Sell, dentist charged with Medicaid fraud and mail fraud; he has been found incompetent and has refused medication; legal standoff has kept him confined without trial for more than four years (L)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court placed strict limits today on the government's ability to medicate mentally ill defendants forcibly to make them competent to stand trial.    The use of antipsychotic drugs must be in the defendant's best medical interest and...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Jewish population of New York City has fallen by 5 percent since 1991, dipping below one million for the first time in a century, according to a roughly once-a-decade study that is being released today by the UJA-Federation of New York. But Jews who left the city seemed to stay in the area, because the Jewish population has risen by a corresponding amount in three suburban counties in New York state.

headline.main: City Milestone: Number of Jews Is Below Million

docs.abstract: UJA-Federation of New York study finds that Jewish population of New York City has fallen five percent since 1991, dipping below one million for first time in century; Jewish population has risen by corresponding amount in three suburban counties; 972,000 Jews lived in city in 2002, compared with two million in late 1950's, and decline would have been steeper if not for influx from former Soviet Union; city, Long Island and Westchester have about 1.4 million Jewish residents (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In one of the most successful efforts to rein in the fast-rising cost of Medicaid, the government health plan for the poor, states are limiting which drugs doctors can prescribe for Medicaid patients. Two years ago, only three states had authorized the use of lists of preferred drugs for such patients; since then, 19 other states have done so, though not all their programs are up and running, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.

headline.main: 22 STATES LIMITING DOCTORS' LATITUDE IN MEDICAID DRUGS

docs.abstract: Twenty-two states are limiting which drugs doctors can prescribe for Medicaid patients in one of most successful efforts to rein in fast-rising cost of program; have established preferred drug lists, or formularies, that steer doctors away from some of most expensive drugs, including Nexium and Prevacid for acid reflux and Vioxx and Celebrex for arthritis pain, and toward different, less expensive ones that they deem equally effective; health care experts say potential savings nationally from use of preferred drug lists could reach into billions of dollars; pharmaceutical industry has spent more than $500,000 in first four months of this year to kill or weaken preferred drug list bill being negotiated by Senate and Assembly in New York, which spends more on Medicaid than any other state (M)
docs.snippet: In one of the most successful efforts to rein in the fast-rising cost of Medicaid, the government health plan for the poor, states are limiting which drugs doctors can prescribe for Medicaid patients.    Two years ago, only three states had...
docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A decision this week by an Ontario appeals court to extend full marriage rights immediately to gay and lesbian couples, after two similar though less sweeping recent rulings in Quebec and British Columbia, appears to have given decisive impetus to efforts to make same-sex marriage a reality across Canada. Dozens of gay and lesbian couples have already rushed to municipal buildings in Toronto, Ottawa and Hamilton to marry without waiting for a decision by Justice Minister Martin Cauchon on whether he will appeal the Ontario court decision to the Supreme Court.

headline.main: Gay Canadians' Quest for Marriage Seems Near Victory

docs.abstract: Decision by Ontario appeals court to extend full marriage rights immediately to gay and lesbian couples appears to have given decisive impetus to efforts to make same-sex marriage a reality across Canada; dozens of gay and lesbian couples rush to municipal buildings in Toronto, Ottawa and Hamilton without waiting for decision by Justice Min Martin Cauchon on whether he will appeal Ontario court decision to Supreme Court; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A decision this week by an Ontario appeals court to extend full marriage rights immediately to gay and lesbian couples, after two similar though less sweeping recent rulings in Quebec and British Columbia, appears to have given decisive impetus to...

docs.lead_paragraph: FEW people paid attention to the minutiae of how older Americans voted in Florida's 1998 election for governor. Susan A. MacManus was one of them, and in her analysis of Jeb Bush's victory, there is an important lesson about Democrats, Republicans and the legendary elderly voter bloc. Professor MacManus, an expert at the University of South Florida in voting trends among the elderly, said she was hardly surprised to learn that voters 65 and older cast their ballots for Mr. Bush's Democratic opponent. After all, it is an axiom of politics that the elderly tend to vote Democratic.

headline.main: The Nation; Baby Boomers Transform an Old Bloc

docs.abstract: Growing importance of elderly voters discussed in light of Pres Bush's support for Medicare package with equal drug benefits for people in traditional Medicare programs and those who join private health plans; ranks of older Americans will grow as baby boom generation ages; elderly, who have tended to vote Democratic, are now seen as increasingly willing to vote Republican; photo (M)
